gurmukhi: guAwrnIXw hir kI sun bwq geI qj lwj kbY js Twno ]rwq ibKY qj JIlih ko nB bIc cilXo ijm jwq tnwno ]615]
transliteration: Guaarneeyaa Har(i) Kisoun Baat Gadtaj Taaj Kabai Jas Thaano|| Raat Bikhai Taj Jheelah(i) Ko Nabh Beech Chaliyo Jim Jaat Tanaano||615||
translation: The gopis, hearing the words of Krishna, forsaking their shyness, they decided to join the lustful play with Krishna in their mind; they appeared moving towards Krishna like a glow-worm rising from the bank of a lake and moving towards the sky.615.

gurmukhi: biRKBwn suqw hir ky ihq gwvq gÍwrn ky su ikDO gn mY ]iem nwcq hY Aiq pRym BrI ibjlI ijh BwNq Gny Gn mY ]
transliteration: Brikhbhaan Soutaa Har(i) Ke Hit Gadvat Gvaaran Ke Su Kidhaudgad Mai|| Im Naachat Hai At(i) Prem Bharibijlijih Bhaant Ghane Ghan Mai||
translation: Radha is singing for Krishna amongst the group of gopis and is dancing like the lightning flashing among the clouds;

gurmukhi: kiv ny aupmw iqh gwieb kI su ibcwr khI Apny mn mY ]ruq cyq kI mY mn AwnMd kY kuhkY mno koiklkw bn mY ]616]
transliteration: Kavi Ne Oupmaa Tih Gadtih Gadib Kisu Bichaar Kahiapne Man Mai|| Rout Chet Kimai Man Aanand Kai Kuhkai Mano Kokilakaa Ban Mai||616||
translation: The poet, praising her singing says that the appears cooling like a nightingale in the forest in the month of Chaitra.616.

gurmukhi: hir ky sMg Kylq rMg BrI su qRIXw sj swj sBY qn mY ]Aiq hI kr kY ihq kwnHr so kr kY nhI bMDn AO Dn mY ]
transliteration: Har(i) Ke San Khelat Ran Bharisu Treeyaa Saj Saaj Sabhai Tan Mai|| At(i) Hikar Kai Bit Kaahnar So Kar Kai Nahibandharn Au Dhan Mai||
translation: All the women bedecked and in extreme love for Krishna and forsaking all the restraints, are playing with Krishna, imbued in his love;

gurmukhi: Pun qw Cib kI Aiq hI aupmw aupjI kib sXwm ky XO mn mY ]mno swvn mws ky m`D ibKY cmkY ijm ib`julqw Gn mY ]617]
transliteration: Phoun Taa Chhah(i) Kiat(i) Hioupmaa Oupjikabi Syaam Ke You Man Mai|| Mano Saayan Maas Ke Maddh Bikhai Chmakai Jim Bijjulataa Ghan Mai||617||
translation: The poet says again that they appear like the lightnings flashing among the clouds in the month of Sawan.617.

gurmukhi: sXwm so suMdr Kylq hY kib sXwm khY Aiq hI rMg rwcI ]rUp scI Aru pY rq kI mn mY kr pRIq so Kylq swcI ]
transliteration: Syaam So Soundar Khelat Hai Kabisyaam Kahai At(i) Hiran Raachee|| Roop Sachiar(u) Pai Rat Kiman Mai Kar Preet So Khelat Saachee||
translation: Those beautiful women, imbued in the love of Krishna, are absorbed in the amorous play; their beauty is like Shachi and Rati and they have true love in their heart;

gurmukhi: rws kI Kyl qtY jmnw rjnI Aru dXos ib`Drk mwcI ]cMdRBgw Aru cMdRmuKI biRKBwn suqw qj lwjih nwcI ]618]
transliteration: Raas Kikhel Tatai Jamnaa Rajniar(u) Dyos Biddhrak Maachee|| Channdrabhagad Ar(u) Channdramoukhibrikhbhaan Soutaa Taj Laajah(i) Naachee||618||
translation: Their amorous sport during day and night on the bank of Yamuna, has become renowned and there, forsaking the shyness, Chandarbhaga, Chandarmukhi and Radha are danching.618.

gurmukhi: rws kI Kyl su gÍwrnIXw Aiq hI qh suMdr BwNiq rcI hY ]locn hY ijn ky miRg sy ijn ky sm qu`l n rUp scI hY ]
transliteration: Raas Kikhel Su Gvaarneeyaa At(i) Hitah Soundar Bhaant(i) Rachihai|| Lochanndhai Jin Ke Mrig Se Jin Ke Sam Tull Na Roop Sachihai||
translation: These gopis have begun very nicely the amorous sport; their eyes are like does and even Shachi does not equal them in beauty’

gurmukhi: kMcn so iqn ko qn hY muK hY sis so qh rwiD gcI hY ]mwno krI kr lY krqw suD suMdr qy joaU bwkI bcI hY ]619]
transliteration: Kanchanndso Tin Ko Tan Hai Moukh Hai Sas(i) So Tah Raadh(i) Gadhihai|| Maano Karikar Lai Kartaa Sudh Soundar Te Jooo Baakibachihai||619||
translation: Their body is like gold and face like moon; it seems that they have been created from the residue of ambrosia, churned our from the sea.619.

gurmukhi: AweI hY Kyln rws ibKY sj kY su qRIXw qn suMdr bwny ]pIq rMgy iek rMg ksuMB ky eyk hry iek kysr swny ]
transliteration: Ooihai Khelan Raas Bikhai Saj Kai Su Treeaa Tan Soundar Baane|| Peet Rane Ik Ran Kasounbh Ke Ek Dare Ik Kesar Saane||
translation: The women have come for the amorous play after dedecking themselves in beautiful raimemts; someone’s garments are of yellow colour, someone’s garments are of red colour and someone’s garments are saturated with saffron;

gurmukhi: qw Cib ky js au`c mhw kib nY Apny mn mY pihcwny ]nwcq BUm igrI DrnI hir dyK rhI nhI nYn AGwny ]620]
transliteration: Taa Chhab(i) Ke Jas Ouchch Mahaa Kabi Nai Apne Man Mai Pah(i)chaane|| Naachat Bhoom Giridharnidar(i) Dekh Rahinahinain Aghaane||620||
translation: The poet says that the gopis fall down while dancing and still their mind wants the continuity of the sight of Krishna.620.
